text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
CCDM 34.4.1.8.4(3) was revised to provide that a request to appoint a receiver must now be approved by the Division Counsel (Small Business/Self-Employed).
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This section supersedes CCDM 34.4.1, dated August 11, 2004. This section also incorporates procedures contained in Chief Counsel Notice CC-2014-010.
Table of Contents
page (

) SB/SE attorneys in the field are responsible for handling cases involving the collection of federal taxes in non-bankruptcy insolvency proceedings. These proceedings include receiverships, assignments for the benefit of creditors, corporate dissolutions, decedents’ estates, and estates of incompetents. (
) For additional reference material see IRM
, Insolvencies, Decedent and Estate Taxes and IRM
, Legal Reference Guide for Revenue Officers, Insolvencies and Decedents’ Estates. (

) The local Insolvency Unit is the point of contact for Field Counsel. That Unit each territory protects the Government’s interests with respect to the of any federal taxes that the Government may claim in non-bankruptcy insol- vencies. The Unit may request assistance from or refer a case to Field Counsel. (

) SB/SE should open a legal file in connection with non-bankruptcy insolvency proceedings when the Insolvency Unit requests legal assistance or refers the Files case for action of a legal nature. For specific rules regarding the opening of receivership cases (for example, reviewing a Form
(DO) letter) or cases involving decedents’ or incompetents’ estates, see CCDM

) Advisory assistance in a case ordinarily will be jacketed as to the type of vency involved. If the case involves a general referral, such as where the refers all receiverships to Field Counsel, it should be counted as post-filing legal advice, not as a Non-Bankruptcy Insolvency. (
) Field Counsel ordinarily should close a file when the issues for which the referred the case to SB/SE have been disposed of. Field Counsel does not need to wait until the proceeding is closed. (

) The Unit may ask Field Counsel for advice concerning a number of issues. Some of these issues may arise concerning matters currently dent of a pending adversary action in court. For example, during a proof of claim review Field Counsel might be asked whether: (cid:
) A proof of claim should be filed in the proceeding (cid:
) Certain items should be included therein (cid:
) A proposed overassessment should be scheduled (cid:
) A proof of claim constitutes an amendment of a proof of claim filed at an earlier time (cid:
) To file a notice of lien during the pendency of the proceeding (cid:
) A set off can be effected where another department or agency of the gov- ernment is indebted to the taxpayer (cid:
) Seizure of property is permissible (

) Questions may arise concerning what action, if any, the Government should take to collect federal taxes due from third persons who are not parties to insolvency proceedings. For example, issues may arise concerning liability or liability for Trust Fund Recovery Penalties under section
(cid:

) Certain items should be included therein (cid:
) A proposed overassessment should be scheduled (cid:
) A proof of claim constitutes an amendment of a proof of claim filed at an earlier time (cid:
) To file a notice of lien during the pendency of the proceeding (cid:

) Seizure of property is permissible Questions may arise concerning what action, if any, the Government should take to collect federal taxes due from third persons who are not parties to the insolvency proceedings. For example, issues may arise concerning transferee

Questions may arise concerning what action, if any, the Government should take to collect federal taxes due from third persons who are not parties to the insolvency proceedings. For example, issues may arise concerning transferee liability or liability for Trust Fund Recovery Penalties under section 6672.

) Insolvency proceedings often involve federal tax controversies that require af- firmative action. Some of these controversies relate to the merits of claimed in federal taxes. Others relate to a multitude of additional questions involving creditors’ rights that may be tried in the proceeding. Some controversies may require the United States: (cid:
) To reclaim trust fund taxes (cid:
) To oppose claims of other creditors (cid:
) To question a compromise sought by the fiduciary (cid:
) To object to claimed fees (cid:
) To require the filing of returns and payment of current taxes by the (cid:
) To oppose efforts by a fiduciary to require the Insolvency Unit to turn over assets seized before the proceeding began (cid:
) To oppose attempts to subpoena Service records (cid:
) To oppose efforts to have Service employees testify (

) When a party objects to the merits of claimed federal taxes before the court, where some other controversy has arisen that affects the interests of the United States in the collection of federal taxes, Field Counsel should consider the questions at issue, examine the pertinent statutes and court decisions, inform the Department of Justice of Field Counsel’s determinations. (

) If Field Counsel determines that the Government should take affirmative in connection with the federal taxes or federal tax liens involved in a proceed- ing, and that the exercise of such affirmative action requires authorization under section
or section
, Field Counsel should prepare and send suit letter under normal case referral procedures to the Assistant Attorney General, Tax Division, Department of Justice. See CCDM
) Decisions adverse to the Government in whole or in part should be brought the immediate attention of the Office of the Assistant Chief Counsel Bankruptcy and Summonses). See CCDM Part
) CCDM

contains special rules for handling significant bankruptcy cases. The procedural rules therein are the same as those to be used for sig- nificant insolvency cases, defined generally as insolvencies having significant tax liabilities, significant or sensitive issues, or significant audit impact. If one these cases arises, Field Counsel should refer to the special rules. (
) When the Service attempts to collect a tax liability in a non-bankruptcy insol- vency case, a related Tax Court case may require coordination. Procedures Tax coordination are outlined in CCDM Part

) Coordination in Insolvency Proceeding. When a controversy arises the legal position or the claim of the United States for taxes in a non- United bankruptcy insolvency proceeding, Field Counsel usually will work directly and Tax the appropriate U.S. Attorney’s Office.
Insolvency proceedings often involve federal tax controversies that require af

firmative action. Some of these controversies relate to the merits of claimed federal taxes. Others relate to a multitude of additional questions involving creditors’ rights that may be tried in the proceeding. Some controversies may require the United States:

case. This controversy might be a formal opposition to the claim of the United States on its merits, an opposition to its claimed priority, the award of priority to another claim, or opposition by the United States to action taken in the proceedings, such as the payment of fees, the allowance of other claims, inordinate delay, and so forth. (

) Generally, a matter will be referred to the Department of Justice: a. As soon as an objection has been filed to a United States claim for taxes in a proceeding. b. Whenever an issue requires a written or oral communication with the on behalf of the United States (other than the filing of the proof of claim the adjustment of a claim as described in CCDM
and CCDM

). c. Whenever an adversary proceeding or a contested matter arises in which the United States is or should be a party or any matter arises in which interest of the United States should be represented in court by counsel. (

) If the Tax Division writes other than a status request letter to Field Counsel, Field Counsel should assume that the Tax Division has taken over ity for the case and all subsequent communications should go to the Tax Division unless the Tax Division directs otherwise. (

) Coordination in Probate Proceedings. In deciding whether to refer a probate matter to the Tax Division or the United States Attorney, counsel should consider the following: a. The U.S. Attorney usually defends the merits of a claim priority in The U.S. Attorney may in turn call on the Tax Division for help. If the is disallowed in whole or in part and further action to collect the tax is necessary, Field Counsel may need to write a suit authorization letter to the Tax Division, e.g., some states provide that if a claim is not allowed, suit must be brought on the claim within

days or the claim is forever barred. b. If a contest develops or if it becomes necessary to compel the personal representative to act on a claim, Field Counsel generally may communi- cate directly with the U.S. Attorney and attempt to obtain compliance without the necessity of a formal petition. c. Field Counsel does not need to write a formal letter to the Tax Division if the requested action is merely to obtain the removal of an administrator an accounting. A letter to the United States Attorney is sufficient. d. If a formal objection to the Service’s proof of claim is filed in probate pro- ceedings, and the case or issue is of some importance, Field Counsel should notify the Office of the Assistant Chief Counsel (Collection, Bank- ruptcy & Summonses), Branch

by telephone before consulting with or writing the United States Attorney. CBS will coordinate the matter with the Tax Division if necessary. e. An urgent matter may necessitate the referral of a case directly to the Attorney to avoid the expiration of the statute of limitations, the of assets, or other action that might prejudice the rights of the United States before the matter can be authorized through the Tax Division. When such a matter requires prereview, Field Counsel should contact CBS, Branch

by phone. The matter will then be referred to the Tax Division as in the normal procedure with the suit letter sanctioning roactive authorization to the Attorney General. Chief Counsel Directives Manual

consider the following: a. The U.S. Attorney usually defends the merits of a claim priority in The U.S. Attorney may in turn call on the Tax Division for help. If the is disallowed in whole or in part and further action to collect the tax is necessary, Field Counsel may need to write a suit authorization letter to the Tax Division, e.g., some states provide that if a claim is not allowed, suit must be brought on the claim within

days or the claim is forever barred. b. If a contest develops or if it becomes necessary to compel the personal representative to act on a claim, Field Counsel generally may communi- cate directly with the U.S. Attorney and attempt to obtain compliance without the necessity of a formal petition. c. Field Counsel does not need to write a formal letter to the Tax Division if the requested action is merely to obtain the removal of an administrator an accounting. A letter to the United States Attorney is sufficient. d. If a formal objection to the Service’s proof of claim is filed in probate pro- ceedings, and the case or issue is of some importance, Field Counsel should notify the Office of the Assistant Chief Counsel (Collection, Bank- ruptcy & Summonses), Branch

by telephone before consulting with or writing the United States Attorney. CBS will coordinate the matter with Tax Division if necessary. e. An urgent matter may necessitate the referral of a case directly to the Attorney to avoid the expiration of the statute of limitations, the of assets, or other action that might prejudice the rights of the United States before the matter can be authorized through the Tax Division. When such a matter requires prereview, Field Counsel should contact CBS, Branch
by phone. The matter will then be referred to the Tax Division as in the normal procedure with the suit letter sanctioning roactive authorization to the Attorney General.

) Notification of Tax Division, Department of Justice. Where notification of the Tax Division is required, Field Counsel should send notification promptly by letter, accompanied by a copy of the proof of claim, the objection thereto, and any pleading, offer, proposed plan, or other relevant documents. As soon as practicable thereafter or within any applicable time limits, a letter discussing the facts and legal principles involved should be forwarded to the Tax Division for any appropriate legal action. a. If any objection to a proof of claim has been filed, or the merits are in troversy, the material forwarded to the Tax Division should include copies of the protests or claims filed by the taxpayer, returns, revenue agent’s reports and workpapers, and the Appeals Office report. b. If collectibility is in issue, the material forwarded to the Tax Division include copies of recent financial statements that the Service may have and tax returns for the period of administration. (

) Referrals of Settlement, Adjustment, or Compromise. To determine whether a settlement, adjustment of a tax claim, or a compromise in a non-bankruptcy insolvency proceeding must be referred to the Department of Justice, see CCDM

) State Court’s Jurisdiction Over the United States. When the Government files proof of claim in state court it risks having submitted to the jurisdiction of the the Merits of court for all purposes, though there may be some circumstances in which the in State Government has a viable argument against the jurisdiction of the state court. any event, there are alternatives to filing a proof of claim, even though rarely used, which should be considered when warranted. (

) Alternatives to Filing Proof of Claim. Field Counsel should consider to filing a proof of claim to avoid the issue of whether a state court has the ju- risdiction to consider the merits of the tax. a. The Government should give notice in writing to the fiduciary of the tax debt owed and rely on
U.S.C. §

A fiduciary is personally liable for a known tax claim to the extent the fiduciary pays, in whole or part, any debt due by the person or estate without first paying the debts owed to the Government where the fiduciary has actual notice of the of the United States. See CCDM

b. The Government may file suit to reduce the assessments to judgment in federal district court to obtain a judgment on the merits of the tax claim attempt to expedite the federal court’s consideration of a pending suit. To the extent that the federal court enters a final order prior to the entry of a final order on the merits of the tax liability in the insolvency proceeding, the state court is bound by the federal court’s order. c. The Government may assert liability against a transferee or third party. A third party may be liable under a contract or under state laws governing transactions such as corporate dissolutions (and a bulk sale). The ment may assert liability against certain distributees of decedents’ and donees of gifts under sections
(a) and (b) for unpaid estate and gift taxes. (
) Generally. A proof of claim must be filed to collect any tax liability from the assets available for distribution in an insolvency proceeding. Claim Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
K

Notification of Tax Division, Department of Justice. Where notification of the Tax Division is required, Field Counsel should send notification promptly by letter, accompanied by a copy of the proof of claim, the objection thereto, and any pleading, offer, proposed plan, or other relevant documents. As soon as practicable thereafter or within any applicable time limits, a letter discussing the facts and legal principles involved should be forwarded to the Tax Division for any appropriate legal action.
a. The Government should give notice in writing to the fiduciary of the federal tax debt owed and rely on
U.S.C. §

A fiduciary is personally liable for a known tax claim to the extent the fiduciary pays, in whole or in part, any debt due by the person or estate without first paying the debts owed to the Government where the fiduciary has actual notice of the claim of the United States. See CCDM

b. The Government may file suit to reduce the assessments to judgment in federal district court to obtain a judgment on the merits of the tax claim or attempt to expedite the federal court’s consideration of a pending suit. To the extent that the federal court enters a final order prior to the entry of a final order on the merits of the tax liability in the insolvency proceeding, the state court is bound by the federal court’s order. c. The Government may assert liability against a transferee or third party. A third party may be liable under a contract or under state laws governing transactions such as corporate dissolutions (and a bulk sale). The Govern- ment may assert liability against certain distributees of decedents’ estates and donees of gifts under sections
(a) and (b) for unpaid estate and gift taxes.
Generally. A proof of claim must be filed to collect any tax liability from the assets available for distribution in an insolvency proceeding.

) Claiming Interest and Penalties. The rules for claiming interest and penalties on proofs of claim in insolvencies and decedents’ estates are contained in
(Filing the Proof of Claim). See Rev. Rul.
) Bar Dates. State statutes of limitations for filing a claim, set by state law or the fiduciary administering the proceeding, may not be applicable to the States. United States v. Summerlin,
U.S.

). To avoid the necessity of litigating the Government’s right to file its claim at a later time, however, the Government should attempt to meet bar dates. a. Should the time for filing claims in a proceeding be likely to expire the administrative processes can be completed and deficiencies or addi- tional taxes contemplated, the Insolvency Unit will notify Field Counsel. b. Field Counsel should seek an extension of time for filing the claim. If an extension cannot be obtained, a proof of claim in an estimated amount may be filed without waiting for assessment. (

) Proposed Overassessment. Before the Insolvency Unit schedules an essment in connection with a non-bankruptcy insolvency proceeding, the may seek the advice of Field Counsel. Upon receipt of a request for advice, Field Counsel should open a legal file. The attorney should consider the ad- ministrative file and particularly the effect of the proceeding upon the overassessment, the right of the Government to any particular setoffs, and other outstanding items of federal taxes or other federal claims. (
) Settlement Jurisdiction. Settlement of claims in non-bankruptcy insolvency ceedings (excluding the adjustment of a tax claim as discussed in paragraph (

) below) generally will be within the jurisdiction of the Department of Because the case will have been referred to DJ for defense or prosecution, Field Counsel should write to the Tax Division setting forth a a. Pursuant to section
(a), any proposed settlement or concession in case resulting in a refund or credit in excess of $
is subject to Joint Committee review. For procedures regarding Joint Committee see CCDM

) Adjusting a Tax Claim. The Service may adjust its tax claim in an insolvency proceeding to reflect the actual tax liability or a subsequently agreed to tax liability without reference to DJ provided no formal objections have been filed to the Government’s proof of claim. The tax liability may be adjusted if quent information indicates that the original claim was excessive in amount part of the original claim is erroneous on the merits (for example, or clerical errors, substantiation of claimed deductions or payments of tax, interest, or penalty). The litigation hazard of any or all of the issues involved will form a basis for making an adjustment. An adjustment may result from a conference after the issuance of a Form
(DO) letter. a. If a claim has been sent because deficiencies have been determined but not assessed, the proof of claim may be reduced without further to DJ provided:
) there has not been an objection filed to the proof of claim;
) there has not been an earlier reference to DJ;
) the reduction not based on the hazards of litigation; and
) the reduction is consistent with the authority of an Appeals Officer to dispose of matters. (
) Offer in Compromise during Proceedings. If an offer to compromise the tax liability of the taxpayer is submitted under section
during
Should the time for filing claims in a proceeding be likely to expire before the administrative processes can be completed and deficiencies or addi

tional taxes contemplated, the Insolvency Unit will notify Field Counsel. Field Counsel should seek an extension of time for filing the claim. If an extension cannot be obtained, a proof of claim in an estimated amount may be filed without waiting for assessment.

Adjusting a Tax Claim. The Service may adjust its tax claim in an insolvency proceeding to reflect the actual tax liability or a subsequently agreed to tax liability without reference to DJ provided no formal objections have been filed to the Government’s proof of claim. The tax liability may be adjusted if subse- quent information indicates that the original claim was excessive in amount or part of the original claim is erroneous on the merits (for example, or clerical errors, substantiation of claimed deductions or payments of tax, interest, or penalty). The litigation hazard of any or all of the issues involved will form a basis for making an adjustment. An adjustment may result from a conference after the issuance of a Form
(DO) letter.

Adjusting a Tax Claim. The Service may adjust its tax claim in an insolvency proceeding to reflect the actual tax liability or a subsequently agreed to tax liability without reference to DJ provided no formal objections have been filed to the Government’s proof of claim. The tax liability may be adjusted if quent information indicates that the original claim was excessive in amount part of the original claim is erroneous on the merits (for example, or clerical errors, substantiation of claimed deductions or payments of tax, interest, or penalty). The litigation hazard of any or all of the issues involved will form a basis for making an adjustment. An adjustment may result from a
a. If a claim has been sent because deficiencies have been determined but not assessed, the proof of claim may be reduced without further reference to DJ provided:
) there has not been an objection filed to the proof of claim;
) there has not been an earlier reference to DJ;
) the reduction is not based on the hazards of litigation; and
) the reduction is consistent with the authority of an Appeals Officer to dispose of matters.
Offer in Compromise during Proceedings. If an offer to compromise the tax liability of the taxpayer is submitted under section 7122 during non-bankruptcy

insolvency proceedings proposing payment of funds not under the jurisdiction of the court, the offer should be referred to Field Counsel, who will determine whether the offer should be processed through DJ or handled by the Service.
especially when the Government does not have a tax lien to rely on for tion. Section
(a) generally requires that taxes be paid before the claims other creditors. For a complete discussion of federal priority, the exceptions thereto, and the fiduciary’s personal liability, see IRM
) Exceptions to
U.S.C. §
(a) include: a. Prior Interests. Section
(a) does not give a federal tax claim priority over a prior perfected interest in property or an interest in property that otherwise has priority under Internal Revenue Code section
Estate of Romani,
U.S.

). b. Administrative Expenses. These are expenses incurred for the general welfare of creditors, and include court costs and expenses incurred to collect and preserve assets. Funeral expenses are deemed to be costs administration. Administrative expenses may be subject to a standard of reasonableness or specific dollar limitations; therefore, state law should consulted. Note that the expense of last illness is not entitled to priority. See Rev. Rul.

c. Family Allowance. A widow’s allowance or family allowance is generally construed as a charge against the estate and, thus, payable before payment of the debts of the decedent. These expenses are given priority over the federal tax claim if in a reasonable amount. See Rev. Ruls.
and
) Debts owed to the Government are to be satisfied from the debtor’s estate only. The Government cannot seek payment from property that has been divested before priority accrues under
U.S.C. §
) Fiduciary Liability. Where the federal priority of
U.S.C. §

(a) applies, fiduciary is personally liable for debts owed to the Government to the extent the fiduciary pays, in whole or in part, any debt due by the person or estate without first paying the debts owed to the Government. See
U.S.C. §
(b); CCDM
; IRM
and IRM
, relating to Personal Liability of the Fiduciary Under
U.S.C. section
) Receiverships are proceedings in state or federal court outside the scope of the Bankruptcy Code where a receiver is appointed to manage the assets of the debtor. (

) There are two types of receiverships: a. A general receivership is one in which the receiver takes control of all of the assets of the debtor. Collection in a general receivership can be on the tax lien or on
U.S.C. §

b. A limited receivership is either one in which specific assets are in the custody of a receiver or a proceeding for the benefit of a specific such as a foreclosing mortgagee. Generally, a limited receivership does not involve an insolvent debtor and collection is based on the tax lien.
a. Prior Interests. Section
(a) does not give a federal tax claim priority over a prior perfected interest in property or an interest in property that otherwise has priority under Internal Revenue Code section
Estate of Romani,
U.S.

). b. Administrative Expenses. These are expenses incurred for the general welfare of creditors, and include court costs and expenses incurred to collect and preserve assets. Funeral expenses are deemed to be costs of administration. Administrative expenses may be subject to a standard of reasonableness or specific dollar limitations; therefore, state law should consulted. Note that the expense of last illness is not entitled to priority. See Rev. Rul.

c. Family Allowance. A widow’s allowance or family allowance is generally construed as a charge against the estate and, thus, payable before payment of the debts of the decedent. These expenses are given priority over the federal tax claim if in a reasonable amount. See Rev. Ruls.

a. A general receivership is one in which the receiver takes control of all of the assets of the debtor. Collection in a general receivership can be based on the tax lien or on

b. A limited receivership is either one in which specific assets are in the custody of a receiver or a proceeding for the benefit of a specific creditor such as a foreclosing mortgagee. Generally, a limited receivership does not involve an insolvent debtor and collection is based on the tax lien. See

) The general rules discussed in CCDM

to receiverships. (

) A case is opened by Field Counsel when a problem is referred from the Area Director’s office or there is a need to provide legal advice in a proceeding. in a. If a receivership case is already open, the review of a Form
(DO) letter will be handled as part of the open case. b. If there is no open case, the review of the Form
(DO) letter will be jacketed, and a case file should be opened under the appropriate case category. (
) The case will usually be closed when review of the Form
(DO) letter has been completed. The receipt of an information copy of a Form
(DO) is not by itself sufficient basis to jacket a case. See CCDM
for a general discussion of the Form
letter procedures. (
) Receiverships are generally filed in state courts pursuant to the court’s equity jurisdiction. See IRM
(Receiverships). (

) In jurisdictions where formal intervention is required by local court rules, the filing of a proof of claim may not suffice. In those jurisdictions, Technical Services should refer the matter to Field Counsel so that action may be to have a Petition for Intervention filed. A suit letter to the Tax Division ing and authorizing intervention is required. (

) If the receivership is in federal court, the Government is to intervene to its rights. Mere reliance on the filing of a claim will not provide the with standing to challenge any action taken in the court proceeding. A suit letter to the Tax Division requesting and authorizing intervention is required. See CCDM
for suit letter preparation instructions and guidelines. (
) A receiver does not fall within one of the protected classes of section

Accordingly, the Service’s lien priority rights in receivership cases will be in governed by comparing the assessment date with the date the receivership proceeding was commenced. Thus, if federal taxes were assessed prior to receivership, the Service can simply rely on its lien rights. If taxes were not assessed prior to the receivership, the Government must rely on its priority rights under
U.S.C. §
(a) as discussed in CCDM
See also IRM
(Priority of Government Claims under
U.S.C. section

) Problems may arise as to whether or not the court has taken sufficient tion of all the taxpayer’s assets to bar administrative or other collection activities on the part of the United States during the proceeding. Ordinarily, United States will not administratively seek collection from assets within the control of the court (in custodia legis) but will take any necessary collection action against property not taken over either in the general receivership or limited receivership. See IRM

A case is opened by Field Counsel when a problem is referred from the Area Director’s office or there is a need to provide legal advice in a proceeding.
Receiverships are generally filed in state courts pursuant to the court’s general equity jurisdiction. See IRM 5.17.13.11(Receiverships).

)). Problems may arise as to whether or not the court has taken sufficient jurisdic- tion of all the taxpayer’s assets to bar administrative or other collection activities on the part of the United States during the proceeding. Ordinarily, the United States will not administratively seek collection from assets within the control of the court (in custodia legis) but will take any necessary collection action against property not taken over either in the general receivership or the limited receivership. See IRM
Field Counsel will be called upon to advise the area director as to the permissible limits of collection action in re- ceivership cases.

) Receiverships are dramatically different from bankruptcy proceedings in that there are no discharge provisions. Thus, any claim filed in the receivership ceeding and not paid would not be subject to discharge, but rather can be collected thereafter from the taxpayer, either by levy or by proceeding in to the same extent as if the receivership had not taken place. Taxes not claimed, of course, would be similarly collectible. The normal ten-year period for collection of the tax after assessment under section
would also be suspended by section
(b) for the period during which the assets of the taxpayer were under the control or custody of the court in the receivership ceeding, and for six months thereafter. See IRM
) For a discussion of the Government’s priority under
U.S.C. §
(a) and general information regarding the Government’s rights against a receiver
U.S.C. §
(b), see CCDM
) The Service can seek the appointment of a general receiver for all of the tax- payer’s assets by filing a suit to foreclose the tax lien pursuant to section Section
(d) provides that a court may appoint a receiver upon request by the Government. See IRM
) (Receiverships). (
) The Government’s suit letter in a section
proceeding should request the appointment of a receiver when necessary for the collection, preservation, orderly liquidation of assets. (
) A request to appoint a receiver must be approved by the Division Counsel (Small Business/Self-Employed). (
) General Information. Section

requires immediate assessment of any ciency in income, estate, or gift taxes at the time a receivership proceeding is commenced. This is an exception to the usual procedure requiring the issuance of a statutory notice of deficiency prior to the assessment of certain taxes. See sections
and
The regulations provide that whenever immediate assessment is made, the fiduciary shall be advised of the assess- ment and the basis upon which the assessment is made. Treas. Reg. §
(c). Thus, when a receiver is appointed, the Area Director issues a Form
(DO) letter for open years if deficiencies have been deter- mined but not assessed. The Form
(DO) letter is similar in content to the
-day letter, even though it is not a document required to be issued by statute. See Exhibit
) Under Section
(c) the Tax Court has no jurisdiction in these cases jurisdiction already exists at the time of the appointment of a receiver. See CCDM
) Reviewing the Form
(DO) Letter. Not all Form
(DO) letters require counsel review before issuance; however, certain Form

(DO) letters be forwarded to Field Counsel for the same review given to certain statutory notices of deficiency. The case file should be forwarded to Field Counsel, but not, it should be requested whenever deemed necessary. The Field Counsel attorney assigned to review the Form
(DO) letter should check to ascertain if a petition has been filed with the Tax Court, and, if so, the two cases should be coordinated. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
K
34.4.1.8.4 (03-24-2016) Receivership Cases Initiated by the United States
Reviewing the Form
(DO) Letter. Not all Form
(DO) letters require counsel review before issuance; however, certain Form

(DO) letters must be forwarded to Field Counsel for the same review given to certain statutory notices of deficiency. The case file should be forwarded to Field Counsel, but not, it should be requested whenever deemed necessary. The Field Counsel attorney assigned to review the Form
(DO) letter should check to ascertain if a petition has been filed with the Tax Court, and, if so, the two cases should be coordinated.
) The Form
(DO) Conference. The Form

(DO) letter invites the fiduciary to request a conference in the event an adjustment is questioned. The Area Director is required to notify counsel’s office of any such If Field Counsel decides to attend, then the office will be involved in the tion of any question raised at the conference. The extent to which office participates in these conferences will depend upon the nature of the troversy, its importance, and the availability of personnel. The decision to participate is made by Field Counsel. (

) Bar Date Expired. If assessment has not been made and the Form letter has not been sent prior to the expiration of the bar date for filing in the proceeding, Field Counsel should be consulted concerning the of personal liability under
U.S.C. §
and/or whether or not the ment should be made and a claim tardily filed in the proceeding. (

) An Assignment for the Benefit of Creditors is a state law proceeding in the debtor (the assignor) transfers all of his property (a general for the a part of his property (a partial assignment) to an assignee, who then liqui- Creditors dates the property and applies the proceeds to the debts of the assignor. IRM
) The general rules discussed in CCDM

) A legal file is opened by Field Counsel after reference from the Area office or on Field Counsel’s own initiative. It is not necessary for a court a Legal File ceeding to be pending in order for Field Counsel to open a file. (
) An offer in compromise that concerns a decedent’s taxes, with no probate pending, should be jacketed as an Offer in Compromise. (

) The decedent’s death does not affect tax liens existing at the time of death. Where the assessment is made after death, the tax lien will not attach to Rights property that has already passed to the decedent’s heirs, devisees, or Estates of legatees. (

) A “receiver,” “liquidator,” or other fiduciary is appointed by the court in a dissolution to oversee the winding up of corporate affairs while the court and determines any controversies that may arise. ) If tangible property is accessible, seizure action might be faster and more propriate than filing suit. (

) In a judicial dissolution, a proof of claim is usually filed and normal tive collection activities are suspended until it is determined that certain in collection activities will not interfere with the court’s administration. (
) In a nonjudicial dissolution, administrative collection activities, including may be appropriate. (
) Taxes can also be collected through assertion of transferee liability, a suit set aside a fraudulent conveyance, and Trust Fund Recovery Penalty dures. (

) Some states provide that stockholders who have received a distribution are liable for unpaid corporate debts to the extent of the distribution. There are three possible means of collection from stockholders: a. If federal tax liens attached to the property before the distribution, the transfer does not divest the tax liens and the property received may be foreclosed in the hands of the stockholders by suit under section b. Transferee liability may be assessed under section
and the ee’s property may be seized and sold in the usual manner. c. Suit may be filed to set aside the transfer as a conveyance in fraud of creditors. (

If at any time it is determined that the interests of the United States are not being protected in a nonjudicial dissolution, a suit to subject corporate proper- ties to payment of tax under section 7403 could be brought, and a receiver can be appointed thereunder. See CCDM 34.4.1.8.4. If this is done, it will probably result in converting the nonjudicial dissolution into a judicial dissolution, after which the proceeding will continue under supervision of the court.
